case_vignette: A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department for right wrist pain and swelling 2 hours after falling on an outstretched hand while playing softball. The pain worsened when he attempted to pitch after the fall. He has eczema and type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and topical clobetasol. He appears uncomfortable. Examination shows multiple lichenified lesions over his forearms. The right wrist is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. There is tenderness to palpation in the area between the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus muscle. The thumb can be opposed actively towards the other fingers. Muscle strength of the right hand is decreased.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have right wrist pain and swelling since I fell on my hand 2 hours ago while playing softball, and it hurts more when I try to throw a ball.
How old are you?
I am 19 years old.
Have you had any previous injuries to your right wrist?
No, I haven't had any previous injuries to my right wrist.
Do you take any medications or have any medical conditions?
Yes, I take insulin and a skin cream, and I have eczema and type 1 diabetes.
Is there any family history of arthritis or other joint conditions?
I don't know about any family history of arthritis or other joint conditions.

Thank you for the information. Based on your symptoms and the recent trauma, it sounds like you may have sustained a wrist sprain or possibly even a fracture. I recommend you see a doctor for a proper evaluation and any necessary imaging to confirm the diagnosis.

**Final Diagnosis:** Possible wrist sprain or fracture
